ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

EMPLOYEE SHARE OPTION SCHEME
(Review of tax implications)


    1. Mr Chew Heng Ching asked the Minister for Finance if his Ministry will review the tax implications of the Employee Share Option Scheme to make the scheme more attractive to employees.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, under our current tax system, when an employee exercises his share option and a gain is realised, the gain is taxable as an employment benefit in the same way as other forms of income such as salary. The taxable benefit would be the difference between the exercise price of the shares and the market price of the shares when issued to the employee.

    Our tax treatment of employee share options is similar to that in Hong Kong, US and UK which also impose tax at the point of exercise. However, the US and UK have qualified/approved share option schemes in which tax is levied at the point of sale as

Column: 444

capital gains at the capital gains tax rate, which is different from the above tax rate. But such capital gains schemes are not applicable in Singapore as we do not tax gains on capital.

    However, the Ministry of Finance is studying possible options to facilitate the use of employee share options to promote entrepreneurship, and this is something which we will do over the next few months.

    Mr Chew Heng Ching (East Coast): I wish to ask the Minister when will this study be completed. He mentioned "over the next few months".

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: I do not wish to give the Member a promise at this stage. But we will do it within a reasonable period.

Column: 444

HYGIENE RATING SCHEME FOR EATING ESTABLISHMENTS


    2. Mr Chew Heng Ching asked the Minister for the Environment if the Hygiene Rating Scheme for eating establishments has been a success.

    The Senior Minister of State for the Environment (Encik Sidek bin Saniff) (for the Minister for the Environment): Sir, the purpose of the grading system of cooked food retail outlets is to give consumers an idea of the outlet's level of hygiene and cleanliness standards, as assessed by my Ministry. The system is also intended to prompt the operator to improve or to maintain the high standard he already has achieved. I must inform the House in this respect, the scheme has worked well.

    When the scheme was first introduced in May 1998, 7,171 food outlets (or 34.5% of all food outlets) were graded "A" and "B". The number of these two categories has increased to 8,313 (or 38.7%), an increase of 4.2% of grade "A" and grade "B". Generally, feedback from both the public as well as food retailers has been very positive.

    Mr Chew Heng Ching: Sir, I wish to ask the Senior Minister of State whether he will tell the House the criteria for the assessment and how frequent is the

Column: 445

assessment made and whether MOE can step up its frequency of review and assessment of the food establishments.

    Encik Sidek bin Saniff: There are only two important criteria. Sir, first, the hygiene of the person who is involved. The second criterion is the standard of cleanliness of that outlet. Generally, we assess the shop or outlet once a year. But there is leeway for him to make it earlier, for instance, the food outlet may request for reassessment if his premises undergoes extensive renovation.

    Mr Chew Heng Ching: I think the Senior Minister of State has not answered my second question. I have one other supplementary question and, that is, whether the location of the food establishment is one of the criteria.

    Encik Sidek bin Saniff: We have never stipulated that.

    Mr Chew Heng Ching: How about the frequency of review?

    Encik Sidek bin Saniff: It is once a year, or when they have spent a lot of money on renovation, they can call us and we will consider it.

    Mr Chew Heng Ching: Would the Senior Minister of State step up the frequency of review to, say, twice a year in order to uphold the standard of hygiene?

    Encik Sidek bin Saniff: As of now, it is once a year. But for those with "D" grade, we allow them an earlier review, for instance, once in three months. For the rest, in order to see how good they are, we give them up to one year. But if they have extensive renovation, they can just write a letter to my Ministry and we will assess them.

    Mr Chew Heng Ching: Would the Minister consider requests by CCCs or constituencies inviting the Ministry of the Environment to go in to review the food establishment as and when necessary?

Column: 446



    Encik Sidek bin Saniff: You are not talking about one outlet. You are talking about the whole area or centre. We may consider the request.

    Head N (cont.) -

    Resumption of Debate on Question [10th March, 1999],

    "That the total sum to be allocated for Head N of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100." - [Mr Shriniwas Rai].

    Question again proposed.

    The Chairman: Head N - Ministry of Finance. Amendment No. (1). Mr Leong and Mr Chng are not here. Mr Chuang.

    Mr Chuang Shaw Peng (Nominated Member): Sir, I would like to request permission to circulate a table. [Copies of Table distributed to hon. Members].

    All along, the Singapore Government has subscribed to the policy of having an open economy. It believes that a free and fair market will derive the most benefits for the nation in the long run. The recent incident whereby TAS asked SingTel to show cause why their latest pricing was not predatory and the subsequent heated debate in this House affirmed the belief that the Government has always wanted to ensure that the playing field is level, and free and fair market is maintained. At the administrative level, this belief has been translated into the Government procurement policy and implemented by the Finance Ministry all these years and,

Column: 447

that is, in any public open tender, the bids must be competitive and the award goes to the lowest bid with substantial compliance with the specifications.

    For those who have studied economics, this procurement policy can be said to meet the requirements for optimum consumer and producer benefits based on the assumptions that the following conditions are met:

    (1) There must be a large number of competitors;

    (2) The competitors are about the same size;

    (3) The competitors are provided with the same information;

    (4) The competitors will have the same product quality; and

    (5) Free entry and free exit for all competitors.

    If one or more of these conditions are not satisfied, the outcome may not be optimum. The interference by TAS was actually trying to make sure that all these conditions are met. However, in other segments of the economy, particularly in the construction industry where most of the development funds will be spent, I observe that the players repeatedly deviate or attempt to deviate from these conditions for their own benefit.

    Sir, I would like to declare my interest here. One typical example of violating free entry conditions is the process of pre-qualification where unreasonable conditions are set to reduce the number of competitors. Another example would be the predatory pricing policy practised by almost all foreign contractors. The table distributed earlier shows that six local construction companies with a turnover of $6.6 billion reported a profit of 2.8% and paid a tax of 1%, that is, $46 million. But seven Japanese companies with a turnover of $6.1 billion, which is almost the same as the local companies, reported a loss of $201 million and paid a tax of 0.4%, that is, $24 million. What is worse is that three Korean companies with a turnover of $4.6 billion reported a loss of $300 million and paid a tax of $14,869.

Column: 448

One Chinese company and one French company also reported losses.

    Sir, anyone who reads this report, which is extracted from our ROC, will straightaway recognise that all these firms are either poorly managed, or they carry out dumping, or they are practising transfer pricing, or doing a combination of the three.

    I would like to ask the Finance Minister whether it is his policy to allow this to happen. I wish to highlight to this House that dumping and transfer pricing are predatory in nature. It helps these firms to increase their ability to grab projects at all times, and thereby crowding out the local firms who honestly price the projects and pay their taxes.

    I would also like to raise the question why these foreign firms could sustain huge losses year after year. Do they still meet our CIDB's registration requirement? And if they are branch offices, is their head office still a viable entity? Sir, let me look at this issue from another angle. I would like to bring up a point made by the Finance Minister two days ago. In his reply to Mr Lim Swee Say, he mentioned that at our stage of development, he would like to have more aesthetically designed buildings and these buildings should also be built for easy maintenance. He has in fact brought home the point that his Ministry believes in paying for good value, and not the cheapest. Hence, again, I agree with Mr Lim that we should save but we should go further by stretching our dollar to the fullest from the present and future benefits. And that is to say, in financial terms, the price we are paying should be the net present value of present and future benefits. Aesthetics, as mentioned by the Minister, can be classified as present benefit and ease of maintenance is of course our future benefit.

    Sir, I beg to urge that the Finance Ministry build into the procurement system more measures to incorporate some other benefits and these benefits can assist SMEs to build capability, just like our previous policy on CONQUAS;

Column: 449

to create jobs; to acquire and retain knowledge; to build community bonding and to be environmentally friendly.

    Many members of this House have brought up this issue in the first two days. Here, I am suggesting a mechanism where all wishes can be fulfilled and yet we still get the most benefit of an open and fair market. By not sticking to the lowest price method, we can adopt the bidding model based on performance specifications or the design-and-build specifications to meet the WTO requirements and to get the most benefit.
12.45 pm

    The Chairman: Order. Mr Chuang, could you wind up because we need to allow time for the Minister to reply to about nine Members? If you use up all the time, I am afraid there will be no more time for reply.

    Mr Chuang Shaw Peng: Yes, Sir. I hope the Minister can see that there is a need to change our mindset and again I want to ask, in line with the call by Mr Lim Swee Say, that we change the mindset of our people. Dr Tan Cheng Bock has called on the Government to care for the people, in the light of our foreign talent policy. I would also like to echo his call by asking the Government to care for the SMEs in the light of unfair competition from overseas. With Government accounting for more than 50 cents for each dollar spent in Singapore, the Government can show that it cares by changing its mindset, that is, it should be left to market forces.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Sir, I will respond to questions raised yesterday, beginning with Mr Lim Swee Say. Mr Lim has asked whether Government could consider granting pioneer status or special investment allowances to companies which are proceeding to move into the knowledge-based industries, as this is the future we envisage for our country. I can assure Mr Lim that the Government recognises the need to transform Singapore into a knowledge-based economy so that we

Column: 450

have been constantly revising our incentives to try to meet new requirements. For example, in the 1998 Budget, I have already announced an Approved Cyber Trading incentive scheme to encourage companies to take advantage of trading over the Internet and several other existing tax incentives, such as the pioneer status, the Development Expansion incentive and double tax deductions for research and development, already cater to companies engaged in high-value activities in high technology projects which should also cover the knowledge-based type industries. Indicators such as value-added per worker, the profile of the workers and the level of research and development spending are already currently being used to evaluate the awards of these incentives.

    However, I should point out that to achieve what we aim to do, the tax incentives granted must be focused. Otherwise, we will be giving away money without any specific objective in mind. For example, if we simply give tax incentives for whichever company claims to be investing in manpower redevelopment, the dispensation of such tax advantages would be too broad to have any direct focus or desired outcome. However, agencies such as the Economic Development Board can leverage on the granting of tax incentives to get companies to upgrade their manpower capabilities and my Ministry is also always open to consider specific proposals to incentivise manpower development and upgrading and I would ask Mr Lim to let us have his specific views which we will consider. I can assure him that they will be well-received. But we need to know specifically what is needed, and in which directions should we give these incentives because it is obviously not possible to try and give broad incentives covering all sectors because that will be far too costly. As Mr Lim himself has said, there are already referral schemes by Government to facilitate and fund continuous learning, but more can be done if this is necessary. The Manpower 21 Committee is also looking into ways to promote lifelong learning and upgrading in our workforce.

Column: 451



    Mr Inderjit Singh has raised the issue of helping our local traders grow by providing trade financing. He is quite right in saying that small traders form an important part of our economy, and, therefore we should try and help them whenever we can, and many of these had been hit by the present downturn. However, he has suggested that Government should provide financing along the lines of the Local Enterprise Finance Scheme (LEFS) for trading activities. Alternatively, Government should arrange for local banks or international banks to provide low-cost loans for such purposes.

    I would like to say that the commercial market for trade financing in Singapore is already very well-developed and efficient, since trading has been a long established part of our economy and our entire banking infrastructure is geared up to service this sector. As such, I do not see there is any compelling reason why Government should intervene and extend the LEFS scheme into the trading sector. But if he can put up a specific proposal, we would welcome it.

    Mr Inderjit Singh has also indicated that Hong Kong provides tax exemption for third country trade done outside the economy by a company in Hong Kong. I should point out that Hong Kong has a different tax rule from Singapore. Such income will be regarded as a foreign source income and therefore not taxed in Hong Kong. In the case of Singapore, such income would be taxed if it is carried out by a company in Singapore as this would be regarded as Singapore source income. However, to promote offshore trading, we have introduced tax incentive schemes such as Approved Oil Traders and Approved International Traders Schemes. Under these schemes, income from offshore trades carried out by approved traders are taxed at a concessionary rate of 10%. These schemes are open to all companies, whether local or foreign, as long as they meet the approval criteria.

    Mr Shriniwas Rai has asked for a review of the tax on the sale of property. Tax rules were changed in May 1996 as a measure to dampen property speculation. The key

Column: 452

change was to impose capital gains tax on property sold within three years. At this point of time, we do not think it is necessary to remove this restriction because genuine home buyers should not be disturbed by this requirement. They ought not to be selling their property within three years. In any case, the tax is on a sliding scale. What we are concerned about is, if this measure is lifted now, and the property sector recovers, we will be faced with the same problem again and will have to re-introduce a new set of regulations. For the time being, I would prefer to leave it be.

    Mrs Lim Hwee Hua has raised concern over the administration of GST, particularly in the cashflow problems faced by the smaller companies and she has asked that the Government could perhaps streamline these procedures to help them. I would like to say that the Government has already several schemes to help ease the cashflow burden of these businesses, including the SMEs, and these include the Major Exporters Scheme, the Bonded Warehouse Scheme and companies with MES status could have GST suspended on imports. In my FY99 Budget speech, I also announced two new schemes to help contract manufacturers and traders who are operating as logistics companies. I do not want to spend any more time on this issue because my time is limited. But if Mrs Lim is interested, I can provide her with more details.

    Mr Sin Boon Ann has raised questions on whether we should not be amending the Companies Act as a comprehensive overhaul of the Companies Act is long overdue. I agree with Mr Sin that the Companies Act has to be amended regularly to ensure that its ambit does not fall behind comparable jurisdictions elsewhere. In particular, it should be updated to ensure the provisions do not inhibit or place obstacles in the path of new economic activities. This is especially important at the present time when we are trying to restructure rapidly to a knowledge economy.

    Mr Sin has also suggested that we scrutinize changes made in other

Column: 453

countries such as Australia. We will indeed be looking at all the new schemes which other jurisdictions have proposed to help smaller companies and we will incorporate whatever we consider appropriate. Instead of embarking on a comprehensive review of the Act, it is more prudent and practical to progress in stages to improve the Act and to introduce changes which are needed urgently, rather than try to do a comprehensive review all at once as this will take quite a long time. Otherwise, the total overhaul of the Act at this time will hold back other changes unnecessarily.

    Mr Inderjit Singh also raised questions with regard to changes in our tax laws. He said that our current tax laws are too restrictive and inflexible. Mr Heng Chiang Meng, in his Budget debate speech, also called for a full review of our tax system to ensure that it is totally business-friendly and supportive of the economy's broad goals. I can understand why Mr Inderjit Singh and Mr Heng are being deliberately provocative in making these appeals. Clearly, in these difficult times, they want as much help as possible for our companies, which I think is very laudable. But I hope that they will also understand that the Ministry of Finance, in responding to the needs of businesses, has also to cater to the needs of a wider constituency which is to safeguard the Government's fiscal position.

    To help businesses, we can cut taxes, increase rebates and relax our regulations. But there is a point beyond which we cannot go without fore-going too much revenue and allow too much tax leakage, leading to permanent budget deficits. Striking the correct balance is not an easy process but I believe that up to now, we have not done too bad a job.

    It is also important that we look at our tax system in totality when making comparisons with tax systems elsewhere. One has to look at the overall effective tax burden on businesses, determine the competitiveness of our tax regime, rather than comparing a particular feature in a

Column: 454

tax system with another. Compared to many countries, we have a simple tax system which is not onerous in compliance. Our income tax rates are low. We do not tax foreign source income until it is remitted. We do not have a capital gains tax such as in countries like the United Kingdom and the United States and we allow full imputation for corporate tax. This has made our effective corporate tax burden low compared to other countries.

    I want to stress that the Ministry of Finance and the IRAS review our tax structure regularly with the changing business environment and aims to achieve a tax regime that is conducive and friendly to business. This is our main aim and if Members have constructive ideas, these will be always welcome subject to the caveats I have stated earlier. Any changes we make are not done in isolation but always in consultation with our economic agencies and frequently with feedback from the private sector.

    Mr Singh also puts forward seven specific proposals in great detail. I am afraid that I do not have time to deal with these in full and I suggest that I give him a written reply so that he at least gets a proper response.

    Mr Shriniwas Rai (Nominated Member): Sir, I think the House must be grateful to the Minister for giving very comprehensive replies. He has offered a written response to Mr Inderjit Singh and I hope that he would also give Mr Chuang a written reply as well. With that, Sir, I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

1.00 pm

    The Chairman: Head U, Ministry of National Development. Amendment No. (1), Mr Lew Syn Pau.

Column: 455



    Mr Lew Syn Pau (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head U of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100.

    Sir, this time last year, when I spoke on the state of the property market, the property price index of private residential properties had only dropped about 16% from its peak in the second quarter of 1996. Prices were then back to the level of the first quarter of 1995. Since then, with the full impact of the regional economic crisis felt, it is estimated that by the end of last year, prices have corrected by about 40% from the peak, and this has brought prices back to the 1993 levels.

    This is a matter of grave concern to many. While deflating property values can help improve Singapore's international competitive position, drastic asset price correction of this scale can trigger negative multiplier effects on consumption and investment. It also imposes an additional strain on the banking sector as many credit lines are secured by property assets. Calls for top ups by banks and finance companies not met can lead to reduction in credit lines, defaulting loans, corporate failures and personal bankruptcies. The consequences on the economy can be disastrous, as business failures can lead to mass unemployment and social unrest, as we have seen in Indonesia.

    As I have said before, in my view, it is the duty of Government to do its utmost to stabilise the property market. Despite the actions taken by the Government so far, such as deferring Government land sales programmes, extending the project completion period for Government land sale sites to eight years and so on, according to the property consultants, the prices are still falling against a backdrop of fewer transactions. This problem is obviously a very complex one caused by the regional economic crisis, poor sentiments, tight liquidity, over supply of space and, of course, high land values. It is just a problem of mismatch between the demand and supply.

Column: 456



    According to property consultants, on the supply side, the effective potential supply of residential property is about 30,000 units. The average take up rate, however, is estimated to be only 6,000 units per annum. This means it will take five years, ie, until the year 2003, for the current potential supply of 30,000 units to be absorbed. I would like to ask the Minister whether he agrees with these estimates put up by the property consultants and, if so, what are the implications for the future sale of residential land. Does it mean that we should defer land sales for a few more years beyond 1999?

    On the demand side, consultants have also estimated that by the year 2000, effective total housing stock comprising both public and private units will be 875,000 units, exceeding the housing needs of 797,000 units by 9%. So there will be an excess stock of 80,000 units. Here again, I would like to ask the Minister whether he agrees with these figures and, if so, what are the implications for housing policy. Would the Ministry review the total housing supply in a comprehensive manner, taking into account the demographics of Singapore and let us know what is the long-term sustainable supply that should be planned for?

    Finally, I would like to ask the Minister whether he thinks all the measures currently in place are enough to stabilise the property market, and, if not, what new measures should be introduced. Would the Government consider going into the market to buy back the surplus land at current market prices and return them to the State land bank, or perhaps put them into other alternative uses?

    The other suggestion I made at the debate on the Budget Statement but which was not given a specific response by the Minister for Finance is the possible waiver of stamp duty paid by the purchaser until further notice. Would the Minister look into this proposal also?

    Dr Wan Soon Bee (West Coast): Sir, I listened with great interest what my GPC Chairman has said. I totally disagree with him.

Column: 457



    Between 1992 and 1996, property prices increased by well over 300%. This had brought about a lot of undesirable effects. Owning a private residential property for most Singaporeans, became an impossible dream. Our business costs also escalated and we became uncompetitive. Our efforts to attract foreign talents to Singapore were also hampered, because the cost of housing had become a very serious stumbling block. After the introduction of the anti-speculation measures in May 1996, coupled with the severe regional economic crisis, prices had declined. But the prices are still relatively high compared to other countries.

    The property market has a tremendous impact on the economic performance of the country. It has to be properly managed. Therefore, I would like to urge the Government to closely monitor the sale of land. As we know, the supply of property is inelastic, given the gestation period necessary to bring the supply to the market. I am concerned that if the freeze in Government land sale is continued for too long, it might result in a shortfall when demand picks up. This can lead to a repeat of the boom and bust cycle that is economically unproductive. I therefore urge the Government not to delay the sale of land for too long, in order to maintain greater stability in the property market.

    Mr Shriniwas Rai: Sir, owning a private property is a very desirable ambition, and I think we should encourage it. The only caveat is that in this country, the property market is so volatile. If we take 1981 as a base, a terrace house in Serangoon/Hougang used to cost $40,000. Ten years later in 1991, it was $400,000, 10 times. Nowhere in the world could we have such a high appreciation.

    Finally, I just want to comment on this issue of desalination raised by Prof. Low. Before recommending the technology for our first 30 million gallons per day desalination plant, PUB's consultants had reviewed comprehensively all available technologies. For the first phase of our desalination project, it is important to use a reliable and proven desalination technology. Distillation technology is a tried and proven process for large-scale desalination plants.

    Reverse Osmosis technology has potential for improvements with regard to its application in tropical waters where fouling of membranes is a key concern. In addition, the RO process requires a higher degree of pre-treatment of raw sea water. To better assess the suitability of RO for use in Singapore, a small RO plant of 1 mgd will be built as part of the first phase of our desalination project. Depending on the outcome of tests on the plant, RO will be considered for subsequent phases of the desalination project.
